author: bridge-bot
content:
<drortirosh> why not? on ethereum, a tx is "pending" until mined (~12 sec for next block, or higher if prio is too low)
IIUC, on Starknet you get a promise for inclusion (from the sequencer) faster, but it will get commited to L1 later.
(and the same is true for arbitrum, etc). the difference is that the pending time doesn't depend on the user-supplied priority fee, but by the protocol's L1 schedule. ) (re @eliastzr: On Starknet the simple case is to say that a transaction is: pending & promised for inclusion | mined (successful or reverted) | rejected

whereas in EVM world there is no concept of “pending” from the tooling’s perspective)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<drortirosh> define "reasonable" ...
for normal use-cases, "received by node" is enough, and usually means it will get included.
but this is something you can't trust, so you do wait for mining, and in many cases, for multiple confirmations, against the less-likely reorgs.
with L2, there is an implicit trust on the sequencer. as long as you trust it, "pending" is strong enough, but if you're paranoid (or doing transactions with really high value), then you'd want to a higher confirmation (namely, inclusion on L1)
And if you're even more paranoid, you should also check the forced-inclusion mechanism of the chain, which bypasses the sequencer (AFAIK, only Arbitrum currently has one, but I might be wrong on that)
So your mileage on "reasonable" varies. (re @eliastzr: i guess the important aspect is the ability for tools to give you a reasonable ✅ feedback in under a couple of seconds)
